meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny, folks! It's your boy, here to dish out the lowdown on Broken Roads. I'm not gonna sugarcoat it - this game's got its flaws, but let me tell you, it's also got some serious charm. Now, I know what you're thinking: "Grok, why should I care about a post-apocalyptic RPG set in Australia?" Well, buckle up, mate, because Broken Roads is the real deal.

First off, let's get the negative stuff out of the way. Yeah, the combat's a bit wonky - think clunky animations and too much repetition. And don't even get me started on those fetch quests; I mean, come on, game developers, we're not 10-year-olds playing Minecraft! But hey, that's all part of the package, right?

Now, onto the good stuff! Broken Roads' got some serious philosophical heft going on - like, really makes you think about your choices and their consequences. Reminds me of those old-school RPGs where you actually had to make tough calls (you know, before they started making games for babies). And that world-building? Top-notch! You can practically smell the eucalyptus and taste the vegemite sandwiches.

But what really sets Broken Roads apart is its Aussie-ness. I mean, it's not often you get a game that's genuinely Australian, with actual Australian stories and mannerisms (Fair dinkum!). It's like they took all those clich√©s - crocs, Akubras, bushfires - and turned 'em on their head. You'll be laughing at the Aussie humor, nodding along to the folk tunes, and maybe even learning a thing or two about this crazy country.

So, in conclusion: Broken Roads might not be perfect (who is?), but it's got heart, charm, and some serious Aussie flair. If you're looking for an RPG that'll challenge your morals and make you feel like a true blue Aussie battler, then this is the game for you! Now, if you'll excuse me, I've gotta go grab a flat white and watch some cricket...
